resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: Overview of Funding in UCPath - Course Companion

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Welcome to the Overview of Funding in UCPath training module.

In this course, we will cover the topics listed on the screen.

You can jump to a specific section of this module by clicking the menu link at the top left of the screen to open the menu, and then selecting the slide you would like to view.

If you wish to view the closed captions for this training module, click the speech bubble icon at the bottom of the player.

We have added files relevant to this training under the Resources link.

If you'd like to take notes, please download and print this Course Companion.

At times during this training, we may ask you to click an object on the screen to trigger an action, or click the next button to advance the course.

This course is about 15 minutes long.

Click next when you are ready to get started.

Lets start by discussing Funding Entry.

Funding Entry information identifies the funding source, and allocates earnings across multiple funding sources.
UCPath uses this information to generate payroll accounting entries to interface into the UC Davis Kuali Financial System, also known as KFS.

Data entries were converted from the legacy systems into UCPath during the implementation period.

It is worth noting that there are two methods of data entry in the UC Path system:

Direct Entry and File Upload.

Direct Entry in UCPath is done via the Funding Entry screen.

This function will be used by department, fund & account administrators as well as Service Channel staff.
File Upload is used to update a batch of entries. This function is used by central units only.

Please note: to view funding entries that were generated through batch file uploads or through the initial conversion of legacy data at the time of UCPath implementation, the Funding Entry Inquiry page is the only place to view this information.

In order to understand funding in UCPath, one must first understand Position, a new concept for PPS users.

Funding is associated with the Position, whether filled or unfilled.

Lets take a look at the concept of position in UCPath.

An analogy for a Position is an empty chair, or a box on an organizational chart. It is independent of an employee.

For example, an administrative assistant II position.
It is unfilled until an incumbent (employee) is hired into the position.
A job is the pairing of the position and the person, the employee.

Now that we understand Position, we will review how funding distributions are entered for a Position: filled or unfilled.

As mentioned before, Funding Entry is a separate security role and can be granted to some finance users in your department.

In the legacy system, finance staff had to request payroll staff to enter funding distributions.

Access and workflow are defined by Role and Row level security.


There are separate roles for Funding Entry and Salary Cost Transfers.
Funding Entry and Salary Cost Transfers require Approval prior to being committed to the system.

Both require at least one approver.

Salary Cost Transfers will require a second Approver in Contracts and Grants Accounting (CGA) if moving onto Federal or Federal Flow Through Funds >120 days from original transaction or >90 day after award end date.

Please note that pre-approval must be granted before starting the Salary Cost Transfer process.
The unique security roles in UCPath facilitate direct access for finance staff without granting access to HR information.

Initiators and Approvers can transact for employees within the HR Departments they have been granted access to.

Keep in mind that initiator roles are restricted by their HR department, and approvers can only approve for their HR department.

And, remember, Funding Entry and Salary Cost Transfer transactions are routed by HR Department, not financial org.
Funding entry has three levels. The levels allow entry for a group of positions or for a single position.

Position is the lowest level.

It is a prerequisite to position level funding.

This Level is typically used at UC.

Position Pool is the next level.

This level is not used at UCD or ANR.

Department is the highest level.

It is used to enter or update the Default funding for an HR Department.

This funding will be used if the Funding Entry distribution is left blank.

Hint: Campus and School of Medicine use the Accounts beginning with "UCPT" followed by a three digit number and the Sub Account DEFLT should always be used.
The UCPath system looks for the lowest level when generating the payroll accounting entries.

In other words, the system looks at the employees position and searches for position level funding first,
position pool level funding second, and department level funding last.
If none of the levels are found, the system uses a suspense account as the funding source.

The Departmental Finance Officer reviews and clears expenses posted to the default suspense, or edit error accounts during monthly General Ledger reconciliation activities

Finance officers use the Payroll Expense Distribution report to review transactions. this report is available in Cognos, the reporting system for UCPath.
The Funding Entry Page is configured to accommodate the Location FAU (full accounting unit), called Chartstring in UCPath.

The Full Accounting Unit (FAU), in UCPath also known as Chart String, will appear differently.

A key change is that the Object Code will no longer be entered by the user, but rather derived by the system based on rules programmed by UCD.

It does not appear on screen, but will appear in reporting.

Also, differently from PPS, Org and Fund will be displayed, and a new FAU field is being introduced: the Budget Sub.

This field is used in the derivation of the Object Code and is selected by the user.

Individual Chartstring values are validated upon save, submit, and when the approver approves.

The data cannot be saved if there is an invalid value.

The approval routing in UCPath follows HR Department, the new name for Home Department.

Each position has an HR Department.

This means that the approval workflow will only follow this path. If a Position has multiple departmental funding sources, it will only route to the HR Department approvers.

This will require coordination across departments for multiple funding

Take a look at this routing example.

Linda works at the Department of Internal Medicine, and she is funded by the College of Biological Sciences.
In order for the pay distribution to be correct, a funding transaction is initiated in UCPath by Robert, the budget and finance analyst at the department of Internal Medicine.

Jane is the budget and finance manager in the Department of Internal Medicine. She approves the transaction in UCPath.
Ann is the fiscal officer at the College of Biological Sciences, she reviews Linda's payroll expense in financial reporting.
It is important to keep in mind that the HR department and the funding department must communicate before the entry takes place.

Alternatively, someone outside of the HR Department can also INITIATE the funding entry change. For example, Jackson from the College of Biological Sciences, could initiate the fund entry for Lindas position, however Jane, the approver in the department of Internal Medicine, where the position resides, will still be the approver of the transaction.

Notice that only users with row level security for the HR Department of the Position can initiate and/or approve transactions.

And remember, approval responsibility should comply with PPM Section 330-10. The link to the policy is available on this screen.

Click next to continue.

Now lets talk about Funding Defaults.

Funding Entry (used for funding distributions) does not determine if an employee is paid.

Employees will be paid as long as there is an active Job record even if the Funding Entry Page is blank or has expired funding.

Lets take a look at different funding options here.

There are 3 types of funding: these are employed if something goes wrong with the Funding Distributions in the Funding Entry Page.
They are: Default Funding, Suspense funding, and Edit Error funding.
If funding is blank, it charges the Default funding.
If funding is expired, charge Suspense Funding.
If FAU is expired in KFS after data entry, charge Edit Error Funding.

Note that there are FAUs associated with the HR Department of the Position. If any of these three conditions exist, the FAU for the Position HR Department will be charged. This replaces Continuation Account logic.

Campus leadership has designed a convention for the Default, Suspense and Edit Error FAUs that must be followed.

This schema will facilitate the reporting process for users so that they can easily identify any errors that have occurred.
Observe that for UC Davis Campus, each HR Department is assigned a unique Account, with three Sub Accounts for Default, Suspense, and Edit Error.

And for UC Davis Health, or Medical Center, this schema will be used:

All HR Departments are assigned the same KFS Account, with three Sub Accounts for Default, Suspense, and Edit Errors.

Weve outlined how to designate funding distributions in Funding Entry, and what FAUs get charged when something goes wrong.

FAU can also be identified for a transaction via Funding Overrides.

In select payroll and absence management pages, there is an ability to enter an FAU that should be used instead of the FAU in Funding Entry.

Examples of this include termination pay, or a one-time payment such as a STAR award.

These can have an alternative fund source than the FAU for regular pay, thus the Override capability is available.

There is no unique security role to enter funding overrides.

Users must have role access for the individual pages.

Service Channels will be responsible for entry into these pages, if a unique FAU is needed for the transaction, include it in the service ticket request.

Note that users with Funding Entry access will not have access to these pages, so coordination with Service Channels will be required.

Service Channels will have a way to identify FAUs for overrides.

Putting all that youve learned together.

Now that we understand how UCPath works, take a look at this process flow for a new hire.

One, the Department requests new position or position replacement, via AggieService.

Two, HR Compensation or Service Channel creates or updates the Position

Three: : Service Channel initiates Funding Entry Request

Four: HR Department for that Position reviews & approves the Funding Entry in UCPath. Please note that this is more of a transaction review and audit - the approval to create a new position or assign a specific funding source takes place in the deparrtment before a request is made in AggieService.

Five: Funding Entries can be reviewed from the Funding Entry inquiry page.

Six: Departments initiates and approves changes to Funding Entry.

And finally seven : Funding entry data will be available in the Cognos report system

Click next to continue

When a Salary Cost Transfer is needed, Departments are responsible for initiating and approving the cost transfer transaction.
Remember, transactions are routed based on the HR Department of the Position.

Note that in general Service Channels will not process Salary Cost Transfers.

In the next section of this course, let's check your understanding of the material we just covered.

Thank you for watching!

Visit the UC Davis UC Path website for more training resources and job aids.

If you have questions or suggestions, please drop us an email.

Click next to close the course.
